title: CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation)
steps: Check if the person is responsive and breathing.
Call emergency services immediately if unresponsive.
Place the heel of your hand on the center of the chest.
Push hard and fast — about 2 inches deep, 100–120 times per minute.
If trained, give 2 rescue breaths after every 30 compressions.
Continue CPR until help arrives or the person starts breathing.

title: Bleeding Control
description: Stop severe bleeding quickly and safely.
steps: Put on disposable gloves if available.
Apply firm, direct pressure with a clean cloth or bandage.
If bleeding continues, do not remove the first cloth — add another layer.
Elevate the injured limb if possible.
Once bleeding stops, secure the bandage tightly and monitor for shock.

title: Burn Care
description: For mild to moderate burns caused by heat or chemicals.
steps: Cool the burn under running water for at least 10 minutes.
Remove any jewelry or tight clothing near the burn area.
Cover the area loosely with a sterile, non-stick dressing.
Do not apply ice, ointment, or butter.
Seek medical help for severe burns or large affected areas.

title: Choking (Adult)
description: For adults choking and unable to breathe or speak.
steps: Ask the person if they can speak or cough.
If not, stand behind and give 5 back blows between the shoulder blades.
Follow with 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
Alternate back blows and thrusts until the object is expelled or help arrives.
If the person becomes unresponsive, start CPR.

title: Fracture (Broken Bone)
steps: Keep the injured limb still and support it with a splint if possible.
Do not attempt to straighten a deformed bone.
Apply ice wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling.
Check for circulation below the injury (numbness or color change).
Seek immediate medical attention.

title: Shock Management
description: For victims showing signs of shock after an injury.
steps: Lay the person flat on their back.
Elevate their legs slightly unless there is a leg injury.
Keep them warm and comfortable using a blanket or jacket.
Do not give food or water.
Call for emergency help and monitor their breathing and pulse.

title: Seizure Response
steps: Do not restrain the person.
Clear the area of hard or sharp objects.
Place something soft under their head if possible.
Time the seizure — if it lasts longer than 5 minutes, call emergency services.
After the seizure, place the person on their side to keep the airway clear.

title: Heatstroke / Heat Exhaustion
description: For victims exposed to extreme heat.
steps: Move the person to a cooler place.
Loosen tight clothing.
Cool the person with wet cloths or a cool bath.
Offer water if the person is conscious and able to drink.
Seek medical help if symptoms persist or worsen.

title: Hypothermia
description: For someone showing signs of extreme cold exposure.
steps: Move the person to a warm, dry place.
Remove any wet clothing and cover with blankets.
Offer warm fluids if conscious, do not give alcohol.
Keep the person still and monitor breathing.
Call for emergency help immediately.

title: Allergic Reaction / Anaphylaxis
steps: Check for signs of difficulty breathing, swelling, or hives.
Administer an epinephrine auto-injector if available.
Call emergency services immediately.
Keep the person lying down and monitor their condition.
Be prepared to perform CPR if the person becomes unresponsive.
